docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about a study of 8-year-olds that found that premature birth might hamper brain development misstated the ages of the subjects. They were born in the early 1990's, not 30 years ago.
docs.abstract: Aug 10 article about study of 8-year-olds finding that premature birth might hamper brain development misstated ages of subjects; they were born in early 1990's
docs.snippet: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about a study of 8-year-olds that found that premature birth might hamper brain development misstated the ages of the subjects. They were born in the early 1990's, not 30 years ago.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators asked a court yesterday to stop Utah Medical Products Inc. from making and distributing its obstetrical, neonatal and other medical devices until it fixes manufacturing problems. The Food and Drug Administration said a series of inspections over the last three years uncovered ''a pattern of significant deviations'' from federal manufacturing standards. ''Despite repeated warnings from the F.D.A., including a warning letter following one of the inspections, Utah Medical has consistently failed to ensure that its products are manufactured in accordance with'' federal regulations, the agency said. Utah Medical, based in Midvale, Utah, disputed the charges. ''We are innocent until the government proves otherwise. There's never been an F.D.A. allegation that UTMD is not producing safe and effective products,'' the chief executive, Kevin Cornwell, said in a statement. The F.D.A. is not aware of any harm linked to Utah Medical devices, said Larry Spears, deputy director for regulatory affairs in the F.D.A.'s compliance office.

headline.main: F.D.A. SEEKS TO HALT SALES BY UTAH MEDICAL

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration asks court to stop Utah Medical Products Inc from making and distributing its obstetrical, neonatal and other medical devices until its fixes manufacturing problems (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Babies born prematurely show the effects years later, with parts of their brains significantly smaller when they are 8 years old, researchers said Monday. Boys are more affected than girls, the team at the Stanford, Yale and Brown University medical schools found.
docs.abstract: Stanford, Yale and Brown University researchers conduct study that suggests that pre-term male babies have parts of their brains that are significantly smaller than full-term males; magnetic resonance imaging of pre-term males shows differences in gray matter and white matter; study maintains that findings do not apply to pre-term females; study, which researchers admit has some limitations, is published in Journal of Pediatrics (M)
docs.snippet: Babies born prematurely show the effects years later, with parts of their brains significantly smaller when they are 8 years old, researchers said Monday.    Boys are more affected than girls, the team at the Stanford, Yale and Brown University...

docs.lead_paragraph: When doctors prescribed blood pressure medication for Adiva Berkovitz at the age of 8, her parents were troubled. ''It was scary to think that this small child who wasn't even 10 years old was going to have to be taking medication for the rest of her life,'' said Diane Berkovitz, Adiva's mother. ''You think about high blood pressure as an illness of adults.''

headline.main: Starting Young in Treating High Blood Pressure

docs.abstract: Increase in children with high blood pressure prompts new guidelines for pediatricians suggesting they check pressure regularly beginning at age 3; Dr Bonita Falkner, Jefferson Medical College professor of medicine and pediatrics, explains that increase in weight of children and intake of processed foods are likely reasons for increased blood pressure; prescribing antihypertensive drugs for children who are thought to be in high risk ategory is becoming more commonplace despite lack of information on long-term effects of drugs; life style modification is seen as first-line defense against high blood pressure; medical concerns of leaving high blood pressure in children untreated described; photo (M)
docs.snippet: When doctors prescribed blood pressure medication for Adiva Berkovitz at the age of 8, her parents were troubled.     ''It was scary to think that this small child who wasn't even 10 years old was going to have to be taking medication for the rest of...

docs.lead_paragraph: The little fish are dried and laid out flat and look more like bookmarks than creatures that once swam in water, just another in a galaxy of species on the sidewalks of Chinatown that the police lieutenant -- a neighborhood girl back when the girls were all Parisis and Ciprianos and Russos -- cannot identify by name or purpose. ''Who's in charge here?'' she bellows, deep-voiced, into the store. Curious passers-by join the crowd on the corner of Mott and Grand Streets. She couldn't care less if the fish are dead or still flapping or an endangered species or made of uranium: they are stacked on the sidewalk without a permit, and this store has been warned before.

headline.main: THE PRECINCT: Life in the Fifth; Policing a City Where Streets Are Less Mean

docs.abstract: Special report, The Precint, on New York City's Fifth Police Precinct, which includes Chinatown and Little Italy, 10 years after crime in city began its precipitious drop; police officers are now able to pursue variety of tasks that decade ago would have seemed unimaginably minor; drop in crime has reshaped face of policing in ways small and large, obvious and surprising; Compstat, means of statistically analyzing where and when crimes are occuring, has transformed crime-fighting and is at heart of changes; graph of crime drop; map; photos (L)
docs.snippet: The little fish are dried and laid out flat and look more like bookmarks than creatures that once swam in water, just another in a galaxy of species on the sidewalks of Chinatown that the police lieutenant -- a neighborhood girl back when the girls...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the Grand Central Terminal subway tunnel that connects to the Times Square shuttle -- a distance of about 100 meters -- Marion Jones's face and form, but not her name, grace a series of advertisements on the wall. The ads, appearing nationally, suggest that if you were to step into her shoes, you would be ''faster than you think,'' even fast enough to outrun lawyers.

headline.main: Even When They Can Run, They Surely Cannot Hide

docs.abstract: Summer 2004 Games column discusses American track and field team, which is under intense scrutiny by US Anti-Doping Agency and international organizations, which suspect several athletes of doping and look to ban such athletes from Olympic competition; chart; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Television's Most Persistent Taboo'' by Kate Aurthur [July 18]: Josh Schwartz of ''The O.C.'' has characters speak about ''an appointment at Planned Parenthood'' rather than use the word abortion. Euphemisms often perpetuate misapprehensions and stereotypes; it is my understanding that Planned Parenthood clinics test for pregnancy and make referrals for a variety of services, but many do not perform abortions or other surgeries. SARA JASPER COOK Cortlandt Manor, N.Y.
docs.abstract: Sara Jasper Cook letter responds to Kate Aurthur article on American Television's refusal to deal with question of abortion
